utterances: And people within 30 miles of the volcano has been evacuated.
I read that the government is worried about livestock and pets left behind?
Yes, they are, and today there was a big meeting about what to do about that.

There have been a significant number of livestock, we are told, that actually were already taken into cattle drives south to get out of there by their owners when the evacuation notices first came up.
But, yes, there is great concern.
This is a farming area, people have something in the order of a thousand pets there.
In fact, they are the most easy ones to get out at this moment because this is so isolated.
It really sits on the ocean.
So the only way to get them out of there is boats.

It's very difficult to do with cattle, so they're trying to organize actual cattle drives to the south to get the major livestock out of there, which is eating some of the grass and getting quite sick from it.
NPR's Julie McCarthy speaking to us from Santiago, Chile.
Thanks, Julie.
Thank you.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Michele Norris.
As President Bush played host to the French president today, situation in Pakistan stole the spotlight.
Juggling meetings with Nicolas Sarkozy, Mr. Bush found time to make a phone call to Pakistan's leader, Pervez Musharraf.
He pressed Musharraf to hold democratic elections and to give up his role as the head of the military.
Pakistan was also on the minds of Congress today as the deputy secretary of state testified before the House.
We'll have more on that shortly.
But we'll begin with Sarkozy's visit.
The French president spent time on Capitol Hill before he sat down with Mr. Bush.
Here's NPR's David Greene.
In a speech to both houses of Congress, Sarkozy declared France a friend of the U.S.
but he said friends can disagree and he made clear he thinks President Bush could do more to fight global warming.
He used an interpreter.

(Through translator) Those who love the country of wide open spaces, of national parks, and nature - protected nature reserves - expect America to stand alongside Europe in leading, I repeat, leading the fight against global warming.
Mr.
Bush, for his part, played gracious host to Sarkozy.
He took him to Virginia to tour George Washington's Mount Vernon Estate.
The leaders spoke to reporters but this was overshadowed by news that Mr. Bush had just gotten off the phone with Pakistan's president.
Mr. Bush said he told Musharraf thatâ€¦
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: We believe strongly that - in elections and that you ought to have elections soon, and you need to take off your uniform.
It was the first time Mr. Bush spoke to Musharraf since Pakistan's president declared a state of emergency last weekend.
David Greene, NPR News, the White House.
The economy is humming, but we may be hearing some sputtering as well.
The stock market fell 3% this past Wednesday but later made back some of those losses.
While in the bond market, a key marker of a coming recession has been playing out.
Now the payoff for long-term government debt fell below the yield on short-term debt.
So what are we looking for when the bell rings tomorrow?
Catherine Rampell writes about economics for The Washington Post, and she joins me now.
Welcome.
Good to be here.
So first off, I just want a gut check from you - Wall Street ups and downs, that warning flare in the bond market, but we're also seeing strong consumer spending at the same time.
What is your take on these mixed indicators?

You know, it's an interesting thing because, you know, we saw A-Rod on 60 Minutes with a straight face deny, just lie and said that he had not taken steroids, and then we saw him in the interview with ESPN just a couple of days ago saying again with a straight face that he had.
I don't know what the - whether the public believes him or not, this time, or whether they believe that he did it unknowingly and whether or not they're going to hold him accountable.
Do you think the public is angry, Chad, really briefly, because we got to go to a break.
Yeah, I think they are.
I would think they are.
That's as brief as I can put it.
That will work.
I'll tell you what, we're going to continue this conversation.
We're going to talk more about A-Rod.
We're also going to talk about Miguel Tejada.
Here's the only person who has admitted taking steroids and who has admitted lying before a congressional committee.

So stick around, we're going to come back and talk about that in just a minute.

I'm Tony Cox and this is News and Notes.
We're back now with our sports bloggers.
With us, Chad Brown who writes for Alphablogsports and Greg Lee, the online sports editor for the Boston Globe.
Guys we're talking about steroids and baseball and A-Rod.
One of the things, Chad, that came out of this week was that A-Rod's name was on a list of 104 players who tested anonymously, so they thought at the time, for steroid use in baseball in 2003.
The point being that baseball was trying to see how rampant the use of steroids was at that time.
And the next year they would come in, which they did, with a policy banning it.
Now we have these other names, 103 that have not been released.
What's your opinion about whether or not those names should be protected or disclosed?
I think it depends on when they were doing it and how relevant is to what they're - to their performance now.
But I would say, release them because in this day in age, that list is not going to remain confidential for much longer.
So is it better to have a wholesale release or have it come out piece by piece and have the league have to confirm or deny it.
Well, you know, Greg, some players, I heard Torii Hunter say this on the radio just the other day.
Torii Hunter is now with the Angels, was with the Minnesota Twins, and he and A-Rod were teammates when they were 16 years old on some national team.

And the point that he made was this, someone had it in personally for A-Rod because A-Rod's name was the only one of these 104 that was released, and that the 103 others on that list are probably shaking in their boots.

Yeah, I could see that and really in terms of the case of A-Rod, perhaps that person who released it is probably a Yankees fan, and you know how some Yankees fans are that it's a privilege to wear pin stripes, and he's making a $252 million and he hasn't produced a thing for us.
And not only he's gotten traded to the Yankees, he also got a second contract out of the Yankees when he became a free agent last year so, and he's been kind of fraudulent.
So, yeah I could see some truth to what Torii is saying in terms of the hate-aration(ph) of A-Rod.

One more thing about this before we move on, Chad, and that is spring training begins this weekend, and I'm sure people in baseball had hoped that once the Barry Bonds situation was settled that they could move on pass this.
Now it appears as if this is going to carry now who knows how long into the coming season?
No, you're absolutely right.
I think it's going to be - it's going to hang over the league's head during spring training.
And I think it's only going to be - I don't think it will go away once the season starts, but I think you just have to ride with it.
It's not going anywhere.
It's going to be analyzed; everybody is going to be scrutinized.
You just - it's not going away.
Absolutely.
All right, let's talk about football, somebody who is going away or is he going away?
Brett Favre, the future Hall of Fame quarterback from Green Bay spent the last season with the New York Jets, 18 record-breaking seasons, one Super Bowl championship.
I don't know, Greg.
I'm going to ask you first.
I know Chad's in New York but we're going to go outside of New York City first to see what you make of this decision.
He says he's not coming back.
I kind of believe him.
Why would he?
I think he's done.
I think mentally he's done.
And in reality, even over the last three or four years, you know, you can go back to his days of the Packers, his last day with the Packers.
He brought a kind of a soap opera about him that is really tarnishing, I think, his legacy with him.
I know with me and I know there was a lot of people saying that Brett Favre, just make up your mind, just go away or just play, just quit making it about yourself.

And I think now he realizes that he's done, and I really think that he's going to sit back in Killen, Mississippi and do his thing down there with his family and hunt and do what he does in Mississippi.
I guess there's just stop think about being a quarterback of the Jets, Chad, that it's just hard to give to up.

I'm thinking about Broadway Joe Namath who left and went played with the Rams, I think it was the last year or two of his career, ended on whimper, you might say, and this is similar for Brett Favre isn't it?
It absolutely is.
I mean, I listened to the press conference yesterday and I really heard a man who is at peace with his decision.
It wasn't like last year with all the tears and everything which he was entitled to, or as Greg said, the will or won't he saga.

I mean, when he got traded to the Jets, I had a lot my friends who - in Wisconsin saying, good luck, you're going to get a lot of good but you're going to get a lot of bad which is really the best way to summarize...
Mm hmm.
Really the best way to - really the best way to summarize that situation.
But I'm always - I mean, whether - I think it wasn't a total wash him being here, but I will always remember Brett Favre as a Green Bay Packer.
I always will.
I'm not going to completely forget this year because he definitely had his ups and big time downs...
Oh man, for sure Woody Johnson...
Right.

You know said - he's the owner of the Jets, said in the statement released by the team that considering that Favre came from a totally different environment and joined our team during training camp, his performance last season was, in the words of Woody Johnson, extraordinary.
And I suppose, Chad, you would have to say the first half of the season was extraordinary, maybe good and the second half was extraordinarily bad.
Oh that's the perfect way to put it.
Perfect in being imperfect.
Right.
I mean, especially - I mean, I remember the games against - when he brought them back against New England and the outstanding performance against the Titans.
I mean, heck, he even booted the NSC championship - NSC champion Cardinals for six touchdown passes, which he had never done before.
So there were definitely some ups, definitely some downs, but it really ended on a downer especially when the guy that you released came back in and virtually knocked the Jets out of the playoffs.
